}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|2|6|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tournament.fifadata.com/documents/FWC/2018/pdf/FWC_2018_SQUADLISTS.PDF |title=2018 FIFA World Cup Russia: List of players: Colombia |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=5 |date=10 June 2018 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Quibdó]], Colombia | height = 1.82 m<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/playerprofile.html/carlos-sanchez |title=Barclays Premier League Player Profile |date=2014 |work=web page |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=30 October 2012}}</ref> | currentclub = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | clubnumber = 15 | position = [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|Defensive midfielder]] | youthyears1 = 2003–2005 | youthclubs1 = [[Danubio F.C.|Danubio]] | years1 = 2005–2007 | clubs1 = [[Club Atlético River Plate (Montevideo)|River Plate Montevideo]] | caps1 = 40 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2007–2013 | clubs2 = [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]] | caps2 = 178 | goals2 = 10 | years3 = 2013–2014 | clubs3 = [[Elche CF|Elche]] | caps3 = 30 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2014–2016 | clubs4 = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] | caps4 = 48 | goals4 = 1 | years5 = 2016–2017 | clubs5 = → [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] (loan) | caps5 = 31 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2017–2018 | clubs6 = [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] | caps6 = 9 | goals6 = 1 | years7 = 2018 | clubs7 = → [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] (loan) | caps7 = 14 | goals7 = 0 | years8 = 2018– | clubs8 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps8 = 5 | goals8 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2007– | nationalteam1 = [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] | nationalcaps1 = 88 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 23 September 2018 | nationalteam-update = 3 July 2018 | medaltemplates= {{Medal|Team|{{fb|COL}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Copa América Centenario]]}} {{Medal|B|[[Copa América Centenario|2016 United States]]|}} }} '''Carlos Alberto Sánchez Moreno''' (born 6 February 1986) is a Colombian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfielder]] for English Club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. He is nicknamed ''La Roca'' (''The Rock''), due to his strength on the pitch.<ref name=hart>{{cite news|last1=Hart|first1=Simon|title=Carlos Sanchez interview: Midfielder ready to be a rock for Aston Villa revival|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/carlos-sanchez-interview-midfielder-ready-to-be-a-rock-for-aston-villa-revival-10030341.html|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=The Independent|date=6 February 2015}}</ref>
He began his career at [[River Plate Montevideo]] before moving to [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]] in 2007, where he made 178 [[Ligue 1]] appearances and scored ten goals across six seasons. He later played in [[La Liga]] for [[Elche CF|Elche]] and [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]], the [[Premier League]] for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and [[Serie A]] for [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]].
A full international since 2007, Sánchez has earned over 80 caps for Colombia. He was part of the squads that reached the quarter-finals of the [[2011 Copa América]], [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] and the [[2015 Copa América]], and finished third in the 2016 [[Copa América Centenario]].
==Club career== ===Colombia=== Born in [[Quibdó]], [[Department of Chocó|Chocó]], Sánchez moved to a football school in [[Medellín]] and then onto Uruguayan club [[Danubio F.C.|Danubio]], where he signed his first professional contract in 2003 and was a teammate of [[Edinson Cavani]].<ref name=hart/> However, he was released two years later, making no first-team appearances.
In the summer of 2005, Sánchez joined fellow league team [[Club Atlético River Plate (Montevideo)|River Plate Montevideo]]. He featured in 40 matches during his two-year spell, scoring once.
===Valenciennes=== In July 2007, Sánchez was bought by a group of investors and was assigned to [[Rangers de Talca]], subsequently moving abroad for the first time in his career, by agreeing to a five-year deal with [[Ligue 1]] side [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]]. He made his debut on 4 August, starting in a 3–1 home win against [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]].
Sánchez featured regularly for the side in [[2007–08 Ligue 1|his debut campaign]], and was an ever-present figure during the following seasons. In March 2010, he damaged his [[anterior cruciate ligament]], being sidelined nearly a year.<ref>[http://www.va-fc.com/fr/saison/breves/article/4254/Blessure-de-Carlos-Sanchez.html?pge=202 Blessure de Carlos Sanchez (Carlos Sánchez's injury)]; Valenciennes' official website, 24 March 2010 {{fr icon}}</ref>
After making 148 appearances for the club, scoring 8 goals in the league, Sánchez left the club in the summer of 2012 when his contract expired. After long negotiations with [[Bolton Wanderers]]<ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/bolton-scrap-carlos-sanchez-interest-1234215 Trotters aren't plonkers: Bolton abandon Sanchez chase as his price doubles]; [[Daily Mirror]], 7 August 2012</ref> and [[West Ham United]],<ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/west-ham-transfers-carlos-sanchez-1200870 Carlos whisper: West Ham plot cheeky swoop for Colombia's Sanchez]; Daily Mirror, 1 August 2012</ref> he failed to reach an agreement with any club, and subsequently rejoined his former club Valenciennes on 25 August 2012.<ref>[http://www.mercato365.com/infos-clubs/valenciennes/valenciennes-c-sanchez-en-pret-884835.shtml Valenciennes : C.Sanchez en prêt (Valenciennes: C. Sánchez on loan)]; Mercato 365, 25 August 2012 {{fr icon}}</ref>
===Elche=== On 16 August 2013, Sánchez signed a three-year deal with Spanish side [[Elche CF|Elche]], [[2013–14 Segunda División|freshly promoted]] to [[La Liga]],<ref>[http://www.elchecf.es/primer-equipo/-/asset_publisher/TK7hGIx6FcUn/content/carlos-sanchez-di-mi-palabra-al-elche-y-aqui-estoy- Carlos Sánchez: "Di mi palabra al Elche y aquí estoy" (Carlos Sánchez: "I gave my word to Elche and here I am")] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729074925/http://www.elchecf.es/primer-equipo/-/asset_publisher/TK7hGIx6FcUn/content/carlos-sanchez-di-mi-palabra-al-elche-y-aqui-estoy- |date=29 July 2014 }}; Elche's official website, 16 August 2013 {{es icon}}</ref> for a [[Euro|€]]3.7 million fee.<ref>[http://www.lasprovincias.es/v/20130805/deportes/elche-cf/elche-ficha-colombiano-carlos-20130805.html El Elche ficha al colombiano Carlos Sánchez (Elche signs Colombian Carlos Sánchez)]; Las Provincias, 5 August 2013 {{es icon}}</ref> He made his debut on 24 August, starting in a 1–1 home draw against [[Real Sociedad]].<ref>[http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2013_14/primera/jornada_2/elc_rso/ Zurutuza despierta a la Real (Zurutuza awakes Real)]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 24 August 2013 {{es icon}}</ref>
===Aston Villa=== On 15 August 2014, [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] announced the signing of Sánchez on a four-year contract for an undisclosed fee reported to be around £4.7 million.<ref name=hart/><ref>{{cite news|title=Carlos Sanchez: Aston Villa sign Colombia World Cup star|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28812168|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=15 August 2014}}</ref> His first Villa appearance came eight days later when he replaced [[Charles N'Zogbia]] as a substitute in the 62nd minute of a goalless draw with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] at [[Villa Park]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Keegan|first1=Mike|title=Aston Villa 1–0 Newcastle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28816297|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=23 August 2014}}</ref> He made his first start for the club in their 0–3 home defeat against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 20 September, after illness had ruled out some of his teammates.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|title=Aston Villa 0–3 Arsenal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29187273|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=20 September 2014}}</ref> On 11 April 2015, he was sent off for two yellow cards as the team won 1–0 away to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] at [[White Hart Lane]], causing him to miss their victory over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the [[FA Cup]] semi-final eight days later.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Begley|first1=Emlyn|title=Tottenham 0–1 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32179967|accessdate=21 April 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=11 April 2015}}</ref> Sánchez scored his first goal for Villa on 25 April, an 85th-minute deflected volleyed equaliser away to title holders [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], but [[Fernandinho (footballer)|Fernandinho]] later netted a winner for City.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Emons|first1=Michael|title=Man City 3–2 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32362999|accessdate=26 April 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=25 April 2015}}</ref> He made a 19-minute substitute appearance in the [[2015 FA Cup Final]] on 30 May at [[Wembley Stadium]] in place of [[Ashley Westwood (footballer, born 1990)|Ashley Westwood]], in an eventual 0–4 loss to Arsenal.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Arsenal 4–0 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32856754|accessdate=30 May 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=30 May 2015}}</ref>
===Fiorentina=== On 10 August 2016, after Villa's relegation, Sánchez was loaned to [[Serie A]] club [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] for a [[2016–17 Serie A|season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Carlos Sanchez: Aston Villa midfielder joins Fiorentina on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37035007 |accessdate=20 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 August 2016}}</ref> He made his debut ten days later as a 65th-minute substitute for [[Milan Badelj]] in a 2–1 loss away to reigning champions [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] on the first day of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Juventus 2–1 Fiorentina |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36947770 |accessdate=20 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2016}}</ref> Eight days later, he made his first start in a 1–0 home win over [[Chievo Verona|Chievo]], in which he scored the goal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fiorentina 1-0 Chievo Verona |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/report?gameId=461283 |accessdate=20 June 2018 |agency=PA Sport |publisher=ESPN FC |date=28 August 2016}}</ref> The move was made permanent at the end of the campaign.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gladwell |first1=Ben |title=Fiorentina sign midfielder Jordan Veretout from Aston Villa |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/soccer-transfers/story/3164632/fiorentina-sign-jordan-veretout-from-aston-villa |accessdate=20 June 2018 |publisher=ESPN FC |date=25 July 2017}}</ref>
On 31 January 2018, Sánchez returned to La Liga on loan to [[RCD Espanyol]] for the remainder of the [[2017–18 La Liga|season]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rcdespanyol.com/en/news/carlos-sanchez-new-espanyol-player/_n:6607/|title=Carlos Sánchez new Espanyol player|language=es|date=31 January 2018}}</ref> He made his debut four days later in a 1–1 home draw with [[FC Barcelona]] in the ''[[Derbi barceloní]]'', playing the final four minutes in place of [[Léo Baptistão]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Carlos Sánchez debutó en el juego entre Espanyol y Barcelona|trans-title=Carlos Sánchez debuted in the game between Espanyol and Barcelona |url=http://www.elpais.com.co/deportes/futbol-internacional/carlos-sanchez-debuto-en-el-juego-entre-espanyol-y-barcelona.html |accessdate=20 June 2018 |work=El País |agency=EFE |date=4 February 2018 |language=Spanish}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== On 9 August 2018, Sánchez signed a two-year deal with [[English Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>[https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2018/august/09-august/hammers-sign-colombian-international-carlos-sanchez]</ref>
==International career== Sánchez made his international debut against [[Panama national football team|Panama]] on 9 May 2007. He was then included in the 34-man provisional squad for the [[Copa América 2007]], but later dropped for the final list. He was in the first team for all of [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]]'s matches for [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]] including the 2–1 victory over [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] on 20 November 2007 in [[Bogotá]]. At the [[2011 Copa América]], he started three of Colombia's four matches as they reached the quarter-finals, coming into the team at the expense of [[Gustavo Bolívar (footballer)|Gustavo Bolívar]] after the opening game. He played in all five of Colombia's matches in the FIFA World Cup finals in Brazil in 2014, playing a defensive role which allowed [[James Rodríguez]] and [[Juan Cuadrado]] to be attacking midfielders.<ref name=hart/>
Sánchez was included in Colombia's squad for the [[2015 Copa América]], where he was credited with "dominating" [[Neymar]] during his man of the match performance in the 1–0 group stage defeat of [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in [[Santiago]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/copa-america/83/blog/post/2496317/colombias-win-down-to-carlos-sanchez-dominating-neymar|title=Colombia's win down to Carlos Sanchez dominating Neymar|date=18 June 2015|work=ESPN}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/aston-villa-player-watch-carlos-9478156|title=Aston Villa player watch: Carlos Sanchez dominates Neymar in man of match showing against Brazil|date=18 June 2015|work=Birmingham Mail}}</ref>
He was the first player sent off in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], for handball in the third minute against Japan, giving away a penalty from which [[Shinji Kagawa]] opened the scoring in a 2–1 win for the Japanese; only [[José Batista]] of [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]] was sent off quicker.<ref>{{cite news |title=10-man Colombia Beaten by Japan in Historic World Cup Win for Asia |url=https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/10-man-Colombia-Beaten-by-Japan-in-Historic-Win-for-Asia-20180619-0010.html |accessdate=20 June 2018 |publisher=Telesur |date=19 June 2018}}</ref> Sánchez received death threats for his red card, which were likened by [[BBC Sport]] to the assassination of Colombia player [[Andrés Escobar]] for his own goal at the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]]. Manager [[José Pékerman]] dedicated the team's 3–0 win over [[Poland national football team|Poland]] to the suspended Sánchez.<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Colombia dedicate win to Carlos Sanchez after death threats against midfielder |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44601358 |accessdate=25 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 June 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Sánchez is married to Noelia Polvoria, whom he met in Montevideo.<ref name=hart/>
==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 26 September 2018}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Carlos Sanchez|url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players/player.sd?player_id=49203|website=Soccerbase|publisher=Centurycomm|accessdate=18 December 2014}}</ref>
